thanks for the update. some questions:  Why is there $9.7MM of cash sitting in the Trust?  When is it expected to be deployed? Are these funds earning current interest?  If so how much and what assets/risk are they invested in? How quickly could Maker recapture this cash if needed?  What would be the return process needed? For each underlying loan please include at origination a forecast of monthly of work completed (construction, financial…) and then each month show the actual work versus the forecast.  If a project if consistently behind its forecasts, then reforecast and track the new forecast with monthly actuals, and note that it has been re-forecasted and why and new risk level to Maker.  Thanks

Some editor’s notes:   You’ll notice that some of the reporting dates are not 5/31, but 5/27. 6s operates on end of week reporting. They don’t yet have the reports for the week ending 6/3. I have decided that it’s better to not attempt to guess these numbers given the small discrepancy in dates.   The Vault debt for 6s in April and May is identical because no one has called drip. We’ve included an estimate below the actual figure of what the Vault debt would have been if anyone had called drip on 5/31.   I’m working with @tadeo to figure out how to put some of the key metrics in these reports on-chain so that they are ultimately queryable through something like Dune. Hopefully more on that next month. Until then, I’ve started uploading these reports to Arweave so that there are permanent records of them. Can you confirm the Applicate rate is still at 3% as stated in this report? It is based on the Prime rate that was increased a few month ago, then again, last month at 4%. The applicable rate should therefore be 3.75% in my view without any need for intervention (but we need to fix the SF at some point).  image738×103 19.1 KB

The facility is “programmed” to track the Maker stability fee, so nothing has changed. I’m not sure where you sourced that quote but here is the language from the conformed credit agreement. “Applicable Rate” means, for any day, a rate per annum (rounded, if necessary, to the next 1/16 of 1%) equal to the Prime Rate in effect on such day, plus the Spread as set forth in the applicable Note. The initial Spread shall be -25 basis points.  “Spread” means the difference between the interest rate certified by the Verification Agent on a given date and the Prime Rate.  So if the Prime Rate is 4% and the Maker Stability Fee (as confirmed by the Verification Agent) is 3%, the spread is -1%. It had to be structured this way because the Trustee required an actual benchmark and couldn’t just reference the stability fee - so a bit hacky but it got the job done.

Ok, make sense thanks, so MakerDAO governance need to update the Prime Rate in their SF comp themselves and not wait for the borrower. The understanding in the term sheet is that the spread is -25bps, not -100bps as it is currently. I will let others make a Signal Request if that’s the way to fix that.
Maker Prime Rate? I didnt know it existed

Maker Governance can change the applicable rate on the facility by changing the stability fee on the Vault. For instance, if Governance set the Vault stability fee to be equal to the current prime rate, the Trustee would implement the applicable rate as the prime rate because there is no longer a spread between the two. Conversely it can set the stability fee above prime which would render the spread positive and the applicable rate over prime.

IMO Maker should be generating facilities that reflect its cost of capital and not the TradFi market’s. I’d advocate using DSR as a base rate (Maker’s “SOFR”) and then a fixed spread on top of that for everything…if the Trustee’s would allow it.
seems like Maker should adjust its rate to 4% for implicitly floating rate deals
SebVentures:  I will let others make a Signal Request if that’s the way to fix that.   I’ll do it next week after the Fed meeting. Remind me if no one does it first

Note: This is our first attempt at a report for the Maker community. Thank you to @teej and @christiancdpetersen for helping us to improve it. We plan to continue working with them and the community to continually improve our reporting framework. Please don’t hesitate to leave your feedback. image1920×334 81.9 KB  Was wondering if we could get a little clarity around the phrase “a discrepancy in the amount of debt that Maker perceives it is owed verses the interest which has actually accumulated in the trust account.” At the moment the discrepancy is small, but I’m curious if there are potential consequences if this discrepancy grows significantly. Is the DAI issued still fully backed as that discrepancy grows?
It certainly doesn’t need to be on the forum, but does some DAO affiliate (like a core unit) have copies of documentation on these individual loans? If so, who would that be?

prose11:  Was wondering if we could get a little clarity around the phrase “a discrepancy in the amount of debt that Maker perceives it is owed verses the interest which has actually accumulated in the trust account.”   Yes, let me explain with an example. Let’s say 6S borrows 10M Dai, this is pushed through the secure conduit, to the Trust account, and ultimately downstream to the underlying loans. This is accruing 3% stability fees in MakerDAO on the Dai balance of the Vault and 3% interest pursuant to the credit agreement – all is good. Now let’s say, hypothetically, that 6S pays back the $10M and has a 1 month delay between this repayment and its deployment into the next round of underlying loans. MakerDAO is still accruing stability fees and pushes 25,000 Dai (I did not include compounding for simplicity) to the Surplus Buffer; the Trust does not collect any interest. There is now a discrepancy of 25,000 Dai (so yes, 25,000 “unbacked” Dai in the surplus buffer) that needs to be accounted for. The best analogy I can think of for this situation is how Oracle gas fees are part of the cost of production for a Vault, but are backed out afterwards. I’ll also note that this isn’t a surprise. RWAC flagged this issue in our post “Additional Representations, Risks and Mitigations Related to 6s Capital.” I have also been present on PECU office hours calls where 6S has brought the issue to their attention and brainstormed solutions. This is also presumably why other RWA borrowers using a similar construct have requested a 0% stability fee with the interest to be handled separately. So why doesn’t 6S pay interest on the Vault and not its utilization of the credit agreement? It’s our opinion that this would be very uncompetitive. Revolvers may charge a small non-utilization fee on the unused portion of a line, but they cannot charge the full interest rate. Additionally it would encourage 6S to convert the USD to Dai and pay it back to the Vault in these interim periods, which would render the facility unusable due to these recurring transaction fees. I think with the power of foresight, 6S would have tried to solve this issue by requesting a 0% stability fee and working out the interest separately; there’s an opportunity to do this if they receive their requested scope expansion. Short of that, I don’t think there’s a good way to fix it on the current $15M line without having to heavily (and expensively) redraft the governing documents, as the entire Credit Agreement uses the Vault stability fee as a reference point for the interest rate. Until we see the outcome of MIP72, I think the best option is to track and handle this discrepancy manually.     Ippy:  It certainly doesn’t need to be on the forum, but does some DAO affiliate (like a core unit) have copies of documentation on these individual loans? If so, who would that be?   RWAC has been working with RWF CU to develop a process by which we can share the data/documents involved in our monthly spot check, which includes much of the documentation on the individual loans. But please keep in mind that as we scale, and as we begin to engage regulated counterparties, this kind of “look-through” will become more difficult if not impossible. Borrower privacy laws would prevent a counterparty (such as HVBank) from sharing much of the information that a CU would want to see - mainly because while Maker is conceptually the lender, legally it does not exist. I believe Maker will need to increasingly rely on trusted third parties (e.g. banking regulators) to screen for fraud and errors. Also, in our HVBank MIP6 and in MIP72, a Maker community-sourced committee is proposed to sit at the Trust Sponsor level, which would have a better ability to oversee these facilities.

Just want to confirm @g_dip suspicion on why a 0% stability fee was selected for our proposed MIP21 implementations: a mirrored stability fee (i.e. credit agreement/bond and vault) can easily cause a number of troublesome case when you start mapping them out. Our assesment of MIP21 led us to conclude it simpler, and more desirable for all, to keep 0% stability fee in vault, and keep all economics, covenants, conditions, mechanics etc. embedded into the legally enforcable agreement/bond. Much less chance of confusion/mismatches and no loss of control/enforceability for Maker the via off-chain governance mechanics. For completeness, this assesment/logic has not been tested - yet - by LTS/ @christiancdpetersen  or other relevant CUs.

Let me give some comments on how real world Lenders would approach  this issue.   A  Lender expects the Borrower to tie out their uses of borrowed capital to the last penny in the regular reporting cycle which here is monthly.  An consistent inability to do this would usually result in an Event of Default and closure of the Facility.   A real world Lender would not lend until they had operations and structure that would enable the Borrower to make this exact reconciliation.   The $43K in question are related to the approximately $5.1MM outstanding loan to 6S. This is about .84% which may not seem like much but given Maker only gets 2-3%/year on the 6S loan, this is a significant portion of one year’s interest which is material.   A real world Lender starts charging interest as soon as the money leaves their ‘vault’ and only stops once its returned to their ‘vault’.  As long as the Borrower has control of the funds, they pay interest on it.   This raises broader questions, as Allan rightly notes, regarding what is an appropriate lending structure for Maker.  This can certainly be done at the Trust level but then puts even more focus on the Trust - is it being managed reasonably to protect Maker’s rights and responsibilities as a Lender?  And also according to key DeFi principles such as transparency and trustless?
